text: XVI .
text_tokenized: XVI .

text: As no objection was made to the young people ’s engagement with their aunt , and all Mr. Collins ’s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted , the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton ; and the girls had the pleasure of hearing , as they entered the drawing - room , that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle ’s invitation , and was then in the house .
text_tokenized: As no objection was made to the young people ’s engagement with their aunt , and all Mr. Collins ’s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted , the coach conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton ; and the girls had the pleasure of hearing , as they entered the drawing - room , that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle ’s invitation , and was then in the house .

text: When this information was given , and they had all taken their seats , Mr. Collins was at leisure to look around him and admire , and he was so much struck with the size and furniture of the apartment , that he declared he might almost have supposed himself in the small summer breakfast parlour at Rosings ; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification ; but when Mrs. Philips understood from him what Rosings was , and who was its proprietor , when she had listened to the description of only one of Lady Catherine ’s drawing - rooms , and found that the chimney - piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds , she felt all the force of the compliment , and would hardly have resented a comparison with the housekeeper ’s room .
text_tokenized: When this information was given , and they had all taken their seats , Mr. Collins was at leisure to look around him and admire , and he was so much struck with the size and furniture of the apartment , that he declared he might almost have supposed himself in the small summer breakfast parlour at Rosings ; a comparison that did not at first convey much gratification ; but when Mrs. Philips understood from him what Rosings was , and who was its proprietor , when she had listened to the description of only one of Lady Catherine ’s drawing - rooms , and found that the chimney - piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds , she felt all the force of the compliment , and would hardly have resented a comparison with the housekeeper ’s room .

text: In describing to her all the grandeur of Lady Catherine and her mansion , with occasional digressions in praise of his own humble abode , and the improvements it was receiving , he was happily employed until the gentlemen joined them ; and he found in Mrs. Philips a very attentive listener , whose opinion of his consequence increased with what she heard , and who was resolving to retail it all among her neighbours as soon as she could .
text_tokenized: In describing to her all the grandeur of Lady Catherine and her mansion , with occasional digressions in praise of his own humble abode , and the improvements it was receiving , he was happily employed until the gentlemen joined them ; and he found in Mrs. Philips a very attentive listener , whose opinion of his consequence increased with what she heard , and who was resolving to retail it all among her neighbours as soon as she could .

text: To the girls , who could not listen to their cousin , and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument , and examine their own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel - piece , the interval of waiting appeared very long .
text_tokenized: To the girls , who could not listen to their cousin , and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument , and examine their own indifferent imitations of china on the mantel - piece , the interval of waiting appeared very long .

text: It was over at last , however .
text_tokenized: It was over at last , however .

text: The gentlemen did approach : and when Mr. Wickham walked into the room , Elizabeth felt that she had neither been seeing him before , nor thinking of him since , with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration .
text_tokenized: The gentlemen did approach : and when Mr. Wickham walked into the room , Elizabeth felt that she had neither been seeing him before , nor thinking of him since , with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration .

text: The officers of the ----shire were in general a very creditable , gentlemanlike set and the best of them were of the present party ; but Mr , Wickham was as far beyond them all in person , countenance , air , and walk , as _ they _ were superior to the broad - faced stuffy uncle Philips , breathing port wine , who followed them into the room .
text_tokenized: The officers of the ----shire were in general a very creditable , gentlemanlike set and the best of them were of the present party ; but Mr , Wickham was as far beyond them all in person , countenance , air , and walk , as _ they _ were superior to the broad - faced stuffy uncle Philips , breathing port wine , who followed them into the room .

text: Mr. Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned , and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself ; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into conversation , though it was only on its being a wet night , and on the probability of a rainy season , made her feel that the commonest , dullest , most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of the speaker . With such rivals for the notice of the fair as Mr. Wickham and the officers , Mr. Collins seemed to sink into insignificance ; to the young ladies he certainly was nothing ; but he had still at intervals a kind listener in Mrs. Philips , and was , by her watchfulness , most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin .
text_tokenized: Mr. Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was turned , and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom he finally seated himself ; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into conversation , though it was only on its being a wet night , and on the probability of a rainy season , made her feel that the commonest , dullest , most threadbare topic might be rendered interesting by the skill of the speaker . With such rivals for the notice of the fair as Mr. Wickham and the officers , Mr. Collins seemed to sink into insignificance ; to the young ladies he certainly was nothing ; but he had still at intervals a kind listener in Mrs. Philips , and was , by her watchfulness , most abundantly supplied with coffee and muffin .

text: When the card tables were placed , he had an opportunity of obliging her , in return , by sitting down to whist .
text_tokenized: When the card tables were placed , he had an opportunity of obliging her , in return , by sitting down to whist .

text: “ I know little of the game at present , ” said he , “ but I shall be glad to improve myself ; for in my situation of life---- ”
text_tokenized: “ I know little of the game at present , ” said he , “ but I shall be glad to improve myself ; for in my situation of life---- ”

text: Mrs. Philips was very thankful for his compliance , but could not wait for his reason . Mr. Wickham did not play at whist , and with ready delight was he received at the other table between Elizabeth and Lydia .
text_tokenized: Mrs. Philips was very thankful for his compliance , but could not wait for his reason . Mr. Wickham did not play at whist , and with ready delight was he received at the other table between Elizabeth and Lydia .

text: At first there seemed danger of Lydia ’s engrossing him entirely , for she was a most determined talker ; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets
text_tokenized: At first there seemed danger of Lydia ’s engrossing him entirely , for she was a most determined talker ; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets

text: , she soon grew too much interested in the game , too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes , to have attention for anyone in particular . Allowing for the common demands of the game , Mr. Wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to Elizabeth , and she was very willing to hear him , though what she chiefly wished to hear she could not hope to be told , the history of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy .
text_tokenized: , she soon grew too much interested in the game , too eager in making bets and exclaiming after prizes , to have attention for anyone in particular . Allowing for the common demands of the game , Mr. Wickham was therefore at leisure to talk to Elizabeth , and she was very willing to hear him , though what she chiefly wished to hear she could not hope to be told , the history of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy .

text: She dared not even mention that gentleman .
text_tokenized: She dared not even mention that gentleman .

text: Her curiosity , however , was unexpectedly relieved .
text_tokenized: Her curiosity , however , was unexpectedly relieved .

text: Mr. Wickham began the subject himself .
text_tokenized: Mr. Wickham began the subject himself .

text: He inquired how far Netherfield was from Meryton ; and , after receiving her answer , asked in a hesitating manner how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there .
text_tokenized: He inquired how far Netherfield was from Meryton ; and , after receiving her answer , asked in a hesitating manner how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there .

text: “ About a month , ” said Elizabeth ; and then , unwilling to let the subject drop
text_tokenized: “ About a month , ” said Elizabeth ; and then , unwilling to let the subject drop

text: , added , “ he is a man of very large property in Derbyshire , I understand . ”
text_tokenized: , added , “ he is a man of very large property in Derbyshire , I understand . ”

text: “ Yes , ” replied Wickham ; “ his estate there is a noble one .
text_tokenized: “ Yes , ” replied Wickham ; “ his estate there is a noble one .

text: A clear ten thousand per annum .
text_tokenized: A clear ten thousand per annum .

text: You could not have met with a person more capable of giving you certain information on that head than myself -- for I have been connected with his family , in a particular manner , from my infancy . ”
text_tokenized: You could not have met with a person more capable of giving you certain information on that head than myself -- for I have been connected with his family , in a particular manner , from my infancy . ”

text: Elizabeth could not but look surprised .
text_tokenized: Elizabeth could not but look surprised .

text: “ You may well be surprised , Miss Bennet , at such an assertion , after seeing , as you probably might , the very cold manner of our meeting yesterday .
text_tokenized: “ You may well be surprised , Miss Bennet , at such an assertion , after seeing , as you probably might , the very cold manner of our meeting yesterday .

text: Are you much acquainted with Mr. Darcy ? ”
text_tokenized: Are you much acquainted with Mr. Darcy ? ”

text: “ As much as I ever wish to be , ” cried Elizabeth , warmly .
text_tokenized: “ As much as I ever wish to be , ” cried Elizabeth , warmly .

text: “ I have spent four days in the same house with him , and I think him very disagreeable . ”
text_tokenized: “ I have spent four days in the same house with him , and I think him very disagreeable . ”

text: “ I have no right to give _ my _ opinion , ” said Wickham , “ as to his being agreeable or otherwise .
text_tokenized: “ I have no right to give _ my _ opinion , ” said Wickham , “ as to his being agreeable or otherwise .

text: I am not qualified to form one .
text_tokenized: I am not qualified to form one .

text: I have known him too long and too well to be a fair judge .
text_tokenized: I have known him too long and too well to be a fair judge .

text: It is impossible for _ me _ to be impartial .
text_tokenized: It is impossible for _ me _ to be impartial .

text: But I believe your opinion of him would in general astonish -- and , perhaps , you would not express it quite so strongly anywhere else .
text_tokenized: But I believe your opinion of him would in general astonish -- and , perhaps , you would not express it quite so strongly anywhere else .

text: Here you are in your own family .
text_tokenized: Here you are in your own family .

text: “ Upon my word I say no more _ here _ than I might say in any house in the neighbourhood , except Netherfield .
text_tokenized: “ Upon my word I say no more _ here _ than I might say in any house in the neighbourhood , except Netherfield .

text: He is not at all liked in Hertfordshire .
text_tokenized: He is not at all liked in Hertfordshire .

text: Everybody is disgusted with his pride .
text_tokenized: Everybody is disgusted with his pride .

text: You will not find him more favourably spoken of by anyone .
text_tokenized: You will not find him more favourably spoken of by anyone .

text: “ I can not pretend to be sorry , ” said Wickham , after a short interruption , “ that he or that any man should not be estimated beyond their deserts ; but with _ him _
text_tokenized: “ I can not pretend to be sorry , ” said Wickham , after a short interruption , “ that he or that any man should not be estimated beyond their deserts ; but with _ him _

text: I
text_tokenized: I

text: believe it does not often happen .
text_tokenized: believe it does not often happen .

text: The world is blinded by his fortune and consequence , or frightened by his high and imposing manners , and sees him only as he chooses to be seen . ” “ I should take him , even on _ my _ slight acquaintance , to be an ill - tempered man . ” Wickham only shook his head .
text_tokenized: The world is blinded by his fortune and consequence , or frightened by his high and imposing manners , and sees him only as he chooses to be seen . ” “ I should take him , even on _ my _ slight acquaintance , to be an ill - tempered man . ” Wickham only shook his head .

text: “ I wonder , ” said he , at the next opportunity of speaking , “ whether he is likely to be in this country much longer . ”
text_tokenized: “ I wonder , ” said he , at the next opportunity of speaking , “ whether he is likely to be in this country much longer . ”

text: “ I do not at all know ; but I _ heard _ nothing of his going away when I was at Netherfield .
text_tokenized: “ I do not at all know ; but I _ heard _ nothing of his going away when I was at Netherfield .

text: I hope your plans in favour of the ----shire will
text_tokenized: I hope your plans in favour of the ----shire will

text: not
text_tokenized: not

text: be affected by his being in the neighbourhood .
text_tokenized: be affected by his being in the neighbourhood .

text: “ Oh no -- it is not for _ me _ to be driven away by Mr. Darcy .
text_tokenized: “ Oh no -- it is not for _ me _ to be driven away by Mr. Darcy .

text: If _ he _ wishes to avoid seeing _ me _ he must go .
text_tokenized: If _ he _ wishes to avoid seeing _ me _ he must go .

text: We are not on friendly terms , and it always gives me pain to meet him , but I have no reason for avoiding _ him _ but what I might proclaim to all the world -- a sense of very great ill - usage , and most painful regrets at his being what he is . His father , Miss Bennet , the late Mr. Darcy , was one of the best men that ever breathed , and the truest friend I ever had ; and I can never be in company with this Mr. Darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections .
text_tokenized: We are not on friendly terms , and it always gives me pain to meet him , but I have no reason for avoiding _ him _ but what I might proclaim to all the world -- a sense of very great ill - usage , and most painful regrets at his being what he is . His father , Miss Bennet , the late Mr. Darcy , was one of the best men that ever breathed , and the truest friend I ever had ; and I can never be in company with this Mr. Darcy without being grieved to the soul by a thousand tender recollections .

text: His behaviour to myself has been scandalous ; but I verily believe I could forgive him anything and everything , rather than his disappointing the hopes and disgracing the memory of his father .
text_tokenized: His behaviour to myself has been scandalous ; but I verily believe I could forgive him anything and everything , rather than his disappointing the hopes and disgracing the memory of his father .

text: Elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase , and listened with all her heart ; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry .
text_tokenized: Elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase , and listened with all her heart ; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry .

text: Mr. Wickham began to speak on more general topics , Meryton , the neighbourhood , the society , appearing highly pleased with all that he had yet seen , and speaking of the latter , especially , with gentle but very intelligible gallantry .
text_tokenized: Mr. Wickham began to speak on more general topics , Meryton , the neighbourhood , the society , appearing highly pleased with all that he had yet seen , and speaking of the latter , especially , with gentle but very intelligible gallantry .

text: “ It was the prospect of constant society , and good society , ” he added , “ which was my chief inducement to enter the ----shire .
text_tokenized: “ It was the prospect of constant society , and good society , ” he added , “ which was my chief inducement to enter the ----shire .

text: I know it to be a most respectable , agreeable corps ; and my friend Denny tempted me further by his account of their present quarters , and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance Meryton had procured them .
text_tokenized: I know it to be a most respectable , agreeable corps ; and my friend Denny tempted me further by his account of their present quarters , and the very great attentions and excellent acquaintance Meryton had procured them .

text: Society , I own , is necessary to me .
text_tokenized: Society , I own , is necessary to me .

text: I have been a disappointed man , and my spirits will not bear solitude .
text_tokenized: I have been a disappointed man , and my spirits will not bear solitude .

text: I _ must _ have employment and society .
text_tokenized: I _ must _ have employment and society .

text: A military life is not what I was intended for , but circumstances have now made it eligible .
text_tokenized: A military life is not what I was intended for , but circumstances have now made it eligible .

text: The church _ ought _ to have been my profession -- I was brought up for the church ; and I should at this time have been in possession of a most valuable living , had it pleased the gentleman we were speaking of just now . ”
text_tokenized: The church _ ought _ to have been my profession -- I was brought up for the church ; and I should at this time have been in possession of a most valuable living , had it pleased the gentleman we were speaking of just now . ”

text: “ Indeed ! ” “ Yes -- the late Mr. Darcy bequeathed me the next presentation of the best living in his gift .
text_tokenized: “ Indeed ! ” “ Yes -- the late Mr. Darcy bequeathed me the next presentation of the best living in his gift .

text: He was my godfather , and excessively attached to me .
text_tokenized: He was my godfather , and excessively attached to me .

text: I can not do justice to his kindness .
text_tokenized: I can not do justice to his kindness .

text: He meant to provide for me amply , and thought he had done it ; but when the living fell , it was given elsewhere .
text_tokenized: He meant to provide for me amply , and thought he had done it ; but when the living fell , it was given elsewhere .

text: “ Good heavens ! ” cried Elizabeth ; “ but how could _ that _ be ?
text_tokenized: “ Good heavens ! ” cried Elizabeth ; “ but how could _ that _ be ?

text: How could his will be disregarded ?
text_tokenized: How could his will be disregarded ?

text: Why did not you seek legal redress ? ” “ There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give me no hope from law .
text_tokenized: Why did not you seek legal redress ? ” “ There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give me no hope from law .

text: A man of honour could not have doubted the intention , but Mr. Darcy chose to doubt it -- or to treat it as a merely conditional recommendation , and to assert that I had forfeited all claim to it by extravagance , imprudence , in short , anything or nothing .
text_tokenized: A man of honour could not have doubted the intention , but Mr. Darcy chose to doubt it -- or to treat it as a merely conditional recommendation , and to assert that I had forfeited all claim to it by extravagance , imprudence , in short , anything or nothing .

text: Certain it is that the living became vacant two years ago , exactly as I was of an age to hold it , and that it was given to another man ; and no less certain is it , that I can not accuse myself of having really done anything to deserve to lose it .
text_tokenized: Certain it is that the living became vacant two years ago , exactly as I was of an age to hold it , and that it was given to another man ; and no less certain is it , that I can not accuse myself of having really done anything to deserve to lose it .

text: I have a warm unguarded temper , and I may perhaps have sometimes spoken my opinion _ of _ him , and _ to _ him , too freely .
text_tokenized: I have a warm unguarded temper , and I may perhaps have sometimes spoken my opinion _ of _ him , and _ to _ him , too freely .

text: I can recall nothing worse .
text_tokenized: I can recall nothing worse .

text: But the fact is , that we are very different sort of men , and that he hates me .
text_tokenized: But the fact is , that we are very different sort of men , and that he hates me .

text: “ This is quite shocking !
text_tokenized: “ This is quite shocking !

text: He deserves to be publicly disgraced .
text_tokenized: He deserves to be publicly disgraced .

text: ” “ Some time or other he _ will _ be -- but it shall not be by _ me _ .
text_tokenized: ” “ Some time or other he _ will _ be -- but it shall not be by _ me _ .

text: Till I can forget his father , I can never defy or expose _ him _ . ” Elizabeth honoured him for such feelings , and thought him handsomer than ever as he expressed them .
text_tokenized: Till I can forget his father , I can never defy or expose _ him _ . ” Elizabeth honoured him for such feelings , and thought him handsomer than ever as he expressed them .

text: “ But what , ” said she , after a pause , “ can have been his motive ?
text_tokenized: “ But what , ” said she , after a pause , “ can have been his motive ?

text: what can have induced him to behave so cruelly ? ”
text_tokenized: what can have induced him to behave so cruelly ? ”

text: “ A thorough , determined dislike of me -- a dislike which I can not but attribute in some measure to jealousy .
text_tokenized: “ A thorough , determined dislike of me -- a dislike which I can not but attribute in some measure to jealousy .

text: Had the late Mr. Darcy liked me less , his son might have borne with me better ; but his father ’s uncommon attachment to me irritated him , I believe , very early in life .
text_tokenized: Had the late Mr. Darcy liked me less , his son might have borne with me better ; but his father ’s uncommon attachment to me irritated him , I believe , very early in life .

text: He had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which we stood -- the sort of preference which was often given me . ”
text_tokenized: He had not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which we stood -- the sort of preference which was often given me . ”

text: “ I had not thought Mr. Darcy so bad as this -- though I have never liked him , I had not thought so very ill of him -- I had supposed him to be despising his fellow - creatures in general , but did not suspect him of descending to such malicious revenge , such injustice , such inhumanity as this ! ”
text_tokenized: “ I had not thought Mr. Darcy so bad as this -- though I have never liked him , I had not thought so very ill of him -- I had supposed him to be despising his fellow - creatures in general , but did not suspect him of descending to such malicious revenge , such injustice , such inhumanity as this ! ”

text: After a few minutes ’ reflection , however , she continued , “ I _ do _ remember his boasting one day , at Netherfield , of the implacability of his resentments , of his having an unforgiving temper .
text_tokenized: After a few minutes ’ reflection , however , she continued , “ I _ do _ remember his boasting one day , at Netherfield , of the implacability of his resentments , of his having an unforgiving temper .

text: His disposition must be dreadful . ”
text_tokenized: His disposition must be dreadful . ”

text: “ I will not trust myself on the subject , ” replied Wickham ; “ _ I _ can hardly be just to him . ”
text_tokenized: “ I will not trust myself on the subject , ” replied Wickham ; “ _ I _ can hardly be just to him . ”

text: Elizabeth was again deep in thought , and after a time exclaimed , “ To treat in such a manner the godson , the friend , the favourite of his father ! ”
text_tokenized: Elizabeth was again deep in thought , and after a time exclaimed , “ To treat in such a manner the godson , the friend , the favourite of his father ! ”

text: She could have added , “ A young man , too , like _ you _ , whose very countenance may vouch for your being amiable . ”
text_tokenized: She could have added , “ A young man , too , like _ you _ , whose very countenance may vouch for your being amiable . ”

text: But she contented herself with--“And one , too , who had probably been his own companion from childhood , connected together , as I think you said , in the closest manner .
text_tokenized: But she contented herself with--“And one , too , who had probably been his own companion from childhood , connected together , as I think you said , in the closest manner .

text: “ We were born in the same parish , within the same park ; the greatest part of our youth was passed together : inmates of the same house , sharing the same amusements , objects of the same parental care .
text_tokenized: “ We were born in the same parish , within the same park ; the greatest part of our youth was passed together : inmates of the same house , sharing the same amusements , objects of the same parental care .

text: _ My _ father began life in the profession which your uncle , Mr. Philips , appears to do so much credit to ; but he gave up everything to be of use to the late Mr. Darcy , and devoted all his time to the care of the Pemberley property .
text_tokenized: _ My _ father began life in the profession which your uncle , Mr. Philips , appears to do so much credit to ; but he gave up everything to be of use to the late Mr. Darcy , and devoted all his time to the care of the Pemberley property .

text: He was most highly esteemed by Mr. Darcy , a most intimate , confidential friend .
text_tokenized: He was most highly esteemed by Mr. Darcy , a most intimate , confidential friend .

text: Mr. Darcy often acknowledged himself to be under the greatest obligations to my father ’s active superintendence ; and when , immediately before my father ’s death , Mr. Darcy gave him a voluntary promise of providing for me , I am convinced that he felt it to be as much a debt of gratitude to _ him _ as of affection to myself .
text_tokenized: Mr. Darcy often acknowledged himself to be under the greatest obligations to my father ’s active superintendence ; and when , immediately before my father ’s death , Mr. Darcy gave him a voluntary promise of providing for me , I am convinced that he felt it to be as much a debt of gratitude to _ him _ as of affection to myself .

text: “ How strange ! ” cried Elizabeth .
text_tokenized: “ How strange ! ” cried Elizabeth .

text: “ How abominable !
text_tokenized: “ How abominable !

text: I wonder that the very pride of this Mr. Darcy has not made him just to you .
text_tokenized: I wonder that the very pride of this Mr. Darcy has not made him just to you .

text: If from no better motive , that he should not have been too proud to be dishonest,--for dishonesty I must call it . ” “ It _ is _ wonderful , ” replied Wickham ; “ for almost all his actions may be traced to pride ; and pride has often been his best friend .
text_tokenized: If from no better motive , that he should not have been too proud to be dishonest,--for dishonesty I must call it . ” “ It _ is _ wonderful , ” replied Wickham ; “ for almost all his actions may be traced to pride ; and pride has often been his best friend .

text: It has connected him nearer with virtue than any other feeling .
text_tokenized: It has connected him nearer with virtue than any other feeling .

text: But we are none of us consistent ; and in his behaviour to me there were stronger impulses even than pride . ”
text_tokenized: But we are none of us consistent ; and in his behaviour to me there were stronger impulses even than pride . ”

text: “ Can such abominable pride as his have ever done him good ? ” “ Yes ; it has often led him to be liberal and generous ; to give his money freely , to display hospitality , to assist his tenants , and relieve the poor .
text_tokenized: “ Can such abominable pride as his have ever done him good ? ” “ Yes ; it has often led him to be liberal and generous ; to give his money freely , to display hospitality , to assist his tenants , and relieve the poor .

text: Family pride , and _ filial _ pride , for he is very proud of what his father was , have done this .
text_tokenized: Family pride , and _ filial _ pride , for he is very proud of what his father was , have done this .

text: Not to appear to disgrace his family , to degenerate from the popular qualities , or lose the influence of the Pemberley House , is a powerful motive .
text_tokenized: Not to appear to disgrace his family , to degenerate from the popular qualities , or lose the influence of the Pemberley House , is a powerful motive .

text: He has also _ brotherly _ pride , which , with _ some _ brotherly affection , makes him a very kind and careful guardian of his sister ; and you will hear him generally cried up as the most attentive and best of brothers .
text_tokenized: He has also _ brotherly _ pride , which , with _ some _ brotherly affection , makes him a very kind and careful guardian of his sister ; and you will hear him generally cried up as the most attentive and best of brothers .

text: “ What sort of a girl is Miss Darcy ?
text_tokenized: “ What sort of a girl is Miss Darcy ?

text: He shook his head .
text_tokenized: He shook his head .

text: “ I wish I could call her amiable .
text_tokenized: “ I wish I could call her amiable .

text: It gives me pain to speak ill of a Darcy ; but she is too much like her brother,--very , very proud .
text_tokenized: It gives me pain to speak ill of a Darcy ; but she is too much like her brother,--very , very proud .

text: As a child , she was affectionate and pleasing , and extremely fond of me ; and I have devoted hours and hours to her amusement .
text_tokenized: As a child , she was affectionate and pleasing , and extremely fond of me ; and I have devoted hours and hours to her amusement .

text: But she is nothing to me now .
text_tokenized: But she is nothing to me now .

text: She is a handsome girl , about fifteen or sixteen , and , I understand , highly accomplished . Since her father ’s death her home has been London , where a lady lives with her , and superintends her education . ”
text_tokenized: She is a handsome girl , about fifteen or sixteen , and , I understand , highly accomplished . Since her father ’s death her home has been London , where a lady lives with her , and superintends her education . ”

text: After many pauses and many trials of other subjects , Elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first , and saying,-- “ I am astonished at his intimacy with Mr. Bingley .
text_tokenized: After many pauses and many trials of other subjects , Elizabeth could not help reverting once more to the first , and saying,-- “ I am astonished at his intimacy with Mr. Bingley .

text: How can Mr. Bingley , who seems good - humour itself , and is , I really believe , truly amiable , be in friendship with such a man ?
text_tokenized: How can Mr. Bingley , who seems good - humour itself , and is , I really believe , truly amiable , be in friendship with such a man ?

text: How can they suit each other ?
text_tokenized: How can they suit each other ?

text: Do you know Mr. Bingley ? ”
text_tokenized: Do you know Mr. Bingley ? ”

text: “ Not at all .
text_tokenized: “ Not at all .

text: There are , undoubtedly , many who could not say the same ; but , thanks to Lady Catherine de Bourgh , I am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding little matters . ” Mr. Wickham ’s attention was caught ; and after observing Mr. Collins for a few moments , he asked Elizabeth in a low voice whether her relations were very intimately acquainted with the family of De Bourgh . “ Lady Catherine de Bourgh , ” she replied , “ has very lately given him a living .

text: “ Mr. Collins , ” said she , “ speaks highly both of Lady Catherine and her daughter ; but , from some particulars that he has related of her Ladyship , I suspect his gratitude misleads him ; and that , in spite of her being his patroness , she is an arrogant , conceited woman . ” “ I believe her to be both in a great degree , ” replied Wickham ; “ I have not seen her for many years ; but I very well remember that I never liked her , and that her manners were dictatorial and insolent .

text: ” Elizabeth allowed that he had given a very rational account of it , and they continued talking together with mutual satisfaction till supper put an end to cards , and gave the rest of the ladies their share of Mr. Wickham ’s attentions . text: The two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery , where this conversation passed , by the arrival of some of the very persons of whom they had been speaking ; Mr. Bingley and his sisters came to give their personal invitation for the long expected ball at Netherfield , which was fixed for the following Tuesday .

text: Elizabeth ’s spirits were so high on the occasion , that though she did not often speak unnecessarily to Mr. Collins , she could not help asking him whether he intended to accept Mr. Bingley ’s invitation , and if he did , whether he would think it proper to join in the evening ’s amusement ; and she was rather surprised to find that he entertained no scruple whatever on that head , and was very far from dreading a rebuke , either from the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh , by venturing to dance .
text_tokenized: Elizabeth ’s spirits were so high on the occasion , that though she did not often speak unnecessarily to Mr. Collins , she could not help asking him whether he intended to accept Mr. Bingley ’s invitation , and if he did , whether he would think it proper to join in the evening ’s amusement ; and she was rather surprised to find that he entertained no scruple whatever on that head , and was very far from dreading a rebuke , either from the Archbishop or Lady Catherine de Bourgh , by venturing to dance .

text: “ I am by no means of opinion , I assure you , ” said he , “ that a ball of this kind , given by a young man of character , to respectable people , can have any evil tendency ; and I am so far from objecting to dancing myself , that I shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all my fair cousins in the course of the evening ; and I take this opportunity of soliciting yours , Miss Elizabeth , for the two first dances especially ; a preference which I trust my cousin Jane will attribute to the right cause , and not to any disrespect for her .
